translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty
First Section
Discussion of the Person
Affirmation and denial
Homage to that Blessed One, the Worthy One, the Rightly Self-awakened One.
Is a person found in a real and ultimate sense?
“I affirm.”

original: Yo saccikaṭṭho paramattho, tato so puggalo upalabbhati saccikaṭṭhaparamatthenāti?

translated: “Is that person found in the real and ultimate sense that is the specific nature?”
“That cannot be said.”
“You are refuted.

analyzed: puggalaḥ na upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena no ca vattabbe
translated: but you should not say:

translated: “A person is not found in any of the five categories in a real and ultimate sense.”’
But if you don’t say:🔽‘A person is not found in any of the five categories in a real and ultimate sense,’

original: “sabbesu puggalo nupalabbhati saccikaṭṭhaparamatthenā”ti, no ca vata re vattabbe—

analyzed: puggalaḥ na upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena ati  yam tattha vadesi
translated: ‘A person is found in a real and ultimate sense.’🔽But you say:
‘You should say:🔽“A person is found in a real and ultimate sense,”

analyzed: puggalaḥ na upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena no ca vattabbe
translated: but you should not say:

analyzed: sabbesu puggalaḥ na upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena ati micchā pe
translated: “A person is not found in any of the five categories in a real and ultimate sense.”’
The eighth section is finished.

“Yes.”

original: “atthi puggalo attahitāya paṭipanno”, tena vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: atthi puggalaḥ atta hitāya paṭipanno tena vata re vattabbe
translated: “There is a person who is practicing for his own welfare,” then you should say,
“The body is one thing, the person another.”
What do you say to that?

original: “vattabbe kho—🔽‘kāyoti vā sarīranti vā, sarīranti vā kāyoti vā, kāyaṁ appiyaṁ karitvā esese ekaṭṭhe same samabhāge tajjāte, vuttaṁ bhagavatā—🔽atthi puggalo attahitāya paṭipanno’, no ca vattabbe—
analyzed: vattabbe kho  kāyo iti vā sarīranti vā sarīranti vā kāyo iti vā kāyam appiyam karitvā esese ekaṭṭhe same sama bhāge tad jāte vuttam bhagavatā  atthi puggalaḥ atta hitāya paṭipannaḥ no ca vattabbe
translated: “You should say,🔽‘The body is the body, and the person is the person. Having made the body disagreeable, they are separate, unconnected, and different. The Buddha has said that there is a person who is practicing for his own welfare,

analyzed: aññaḥ kāyo añño puggalo ti micchā
translated: but you shouldn’t say that the body is one thing and the person another.’ That’s a mistaken way of putting it.
If you don’t say,

original: “añño kāyo añño puggalo”ti, no ca vata re vattabbe—🔽“kāyoti vā sarīranti vā, sarīranti vā kāyoti vā, kāyaṁ appiyaṁ karitvā esese ekaṭṭhe same samabhāge tajjāte, vuttaṁ bhagavatā—
analyzed: aññaḥ kāyaḥ añño puggalo ti no ca vata re vattabbe  kāyo iti vā sarīranti vā sarīranti vā kāyo iti vā kāyam appiyam karitvā esese ekaṭṭhe same sama bhāge tad jāte vuttam bhagavatā
translated: ‘The body is one thing, the person another,’ then you shouldn’t say,

analyzed: atthi puggalaḥ atta hitāya paṭipannaḥ ti  yam tattha vadesi
translated: ‘The body is the body, and the person is the person. Having made the body disagreeable, they are separate, unconnected, and different. The Buddha has said that there is a person who is practicing for his own welfare.’🔽What do you say to that?
“You should say,

original: ‘kāyoti vā sarīranti vā, sarīranti vā kāyoti vā, kāyaṁ appiyaṁ karitvā esese ekaṭṭhe same samabhāge tajjāte, vuttaṁ bhagavatā—
analyzed: kāyo iti vā sarīranti vā sarīranti vā kāyo iti vā kāyam appiyam karitvā esese ekaṭṭhe same sama bhāge tad jāte vuttam bhagavatā
translated: ‘The body is the self, or the self has a body, or the body is in the self, or the self is in the body,’ then, having made the body unloved, he would be standing with his feet planted on the same level. This was said by the Blessed One.

original: atthi puggalo attahitāya paṭipanno’, no ca vattabbe—
analyzed: atthi puggalaḥ atta hitāya paṭipannaḥ no ca vattabbe
translated: ‘There is a person practising for his own welfare,’ but it shouldn’t be said that

analyzed: aññaḥ kāyo añño puggalo ti micchā
translated: ‘the body is one thing, the person another.’
(Abbreviated.)🔽The Investigation of Designations.
The Investigation of Movement

original: Puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: puggalo sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: Does a person move from this world to the other world, from the other world to this world?
Yes.

original: So puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: saḥ puggalaḥ sandhāvati asmai lokā param loka parasmai lokā imam
translated: Does that person move from this world to the other world, from the other world to this world?
You shouldn’t say that.

original: Puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: puggalo sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: Does a person move from this world to the other world, from the other world to this world?
Yes.

original: Añño puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: añño puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā param loka parasmā lokā imam lokanti
translated: Does another person move from this world to the other world, from the other world to this world?
You shouldn’t say that.

original: Puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: puggalo sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: Does a person move from this world to the other world, from the other world to this world?
Yes.

original: So ca añño ca sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: saḥ ca añño ca sandhāvati asmai lokā param loka parasmai lokā imam lokanti
translated: Does he himself wander on … from this world to the next world, from the next world to this world?
You should not say so. …

original: Puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: puggalo sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: Does a person wander on … from this world to the next world, from the next world to this world?
“Yes.”

original: Neva so sandhāvati, na añño sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: na iva so sandhāvati na aññaḥ sandhāvati asmā lokā param loka parasmā lokā imam lokanti
translated: Does neither he himself nor another wander on … from this world to the next world, from the next world to this world?
You should not say so. …

original: Puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: puggalo sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: Does a person wander on … from this world to the next world, from the next world to this world?
“Yes.”

original: So puggalo sandhāvati, añño puggalo sandhāvati, so ca añño ca sandhāvati, neva so sandhāvati na añño sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe….
analyzed: so puggalo sandhāvati añño puggalo sandhāvati so ca añño ca sandhāvati na iva saḥ sandhāvati na aññaḥ sandhāvati asmai lokā param loka parasmai lokā imam lokanti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: Does he himself wander on, does another wander on, do both he himself and another wander on, or does neither he himself nor another wander on … from this world to the next world, from the next world to this world?🔽You should not say so. …
You should not say so.

original: “puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokan”ti?
analyzed: puggalo sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: “A person wanders on … from this world to the next world, from the next world to this world.”
“Yes.”
Has it not been said by the Blessed One:
“At most seven times
a person runs back and forth,
makes an end to suffering,
and destroys all the fetters.”
Is there such a teaching?
“Yes.”

original: Tena hi puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti.
analyzed: tena hi puggalaḥ sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: “Well then, a person runs back and forth from this world to the next world and from the next world to this world.”
“You shouldn’t say that.

original: “puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokan”ti?
analyzed: puggalo sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: A person doesn’t run back and forth from this world to the next world and from the next world to this world.”
“Yes.”
But hasn’t the Buddha said that:
‘Bhikkhus, this world is without joy.

original: Pubbakoṭi na paññāyati, avijjānīvaraṇānaṁ sattānaṁ taṇhāsaṁyojanānaṁ sandhāvataṁ saṁsaratan”ti.
analyzed: na paññāyati avijjā nīvaraṇānam sattānam taṇhā sayojanānam sandhāvatam
translated: No beginning is perceived of beings roaming and wandering on, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.’
Is there such a teaching?”
“Yes.”

original: Tena hi puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti.
analyzed: tena hi puggalaḥ sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: “Well then, a person runs back and forth from this world to the next world and from the next world to this world.”

original: Puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: puggalo sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: “A person runs back and forth from this world to the next world and from the next world to this world?”
“Yes.”

original: Sveva puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: su eva puggalaḥ sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: “Is it the same person that runs back and forth from this world to the next world and from the next world to this world?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: Sveva puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: su eva puggalaḥ sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: “Then it is not tenable that “The same person runs back and forth between the two worlds.’
“Yes.

original: Atthi koci manusso hutvā devo hotīti?
analyzed: atthi koci manussaḥ hutvā devaḥ hoti iti
translated: “Is there any human being who becomes a god?”
“Yes.

original: Sveva manusso so devoti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe….
analyzed: su eva manussaḥ saḥ devaḥ iti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: “Is the human being the same as the god?”🔽“No.”

analyzed: su eva manussaḥ saḥ devaḥ iti
translated: “Then it is not tenable that ‘The same human being becomes a god.’
“Yes.

original: Manusso hutvā devo hoti, devo hutvā manusso hoti, manussabhūto añño, devo añño, manussabhūto svevāyaṁ sandhāvatīti micchā …pe….
analyzed: manussaḥ hutvā devaḥ hoti devaḥ hutvā manussaḥ hoti manussa bhūtaḥ aññaḥ devaḥ aññaḥ manussa bhūtaḥ su eva ayam sandhāvati iti micchā pe
translated: “It is false that ‘The same human being becomes a god, a god becomes a human being; the human being and the god are different; the same person runs back and forth between the two worlds.’

original: Sace hi sandhāvati sveva puggalo ito cuto paraṁ lokaṁ anañño, hevaṁ maraṇaṁ na hehiti, pāṇātipātopi nupalabbhati.
analyzed: sace hi sandhāvati su eva puggalaḥ itas cutas param lokam anaññaḥ ha ivam maraṇam na pāṇa atipātaḥ api na upalabbhati
translated: “If the same person runs back and forth between the two worlds, and if death is not another, then killing would not be apprehended.

original: Kammaṁ atthi, kammavipāko atthi, katānaṁ kammānaṁ vipāko atthi, kusalākusale vipaccamāne svevāyaṁ sandhāvatīti micchā.
analyzed: kammam atthi kamma vipākaḥ atthi katānam kammānam vipākaḥ atthi kusala akusale vipaccamāne su eva ayam sandhāvati iti micchā
translated: It is false that ‘there is action, there is result, there is action and result, and the same person runs back and forth between the two worlds experiencing the result of action.’

original: Sveva puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: su eva puggalaḥ sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: “Then it is not tenable that ‘The same person runs back and forth between the two worlds.’
“Yes.

original: Atthi koci manusso hutvā yakkho hoti, peto hoti, nerayiko hoti, tiracchānagato hoti, oṭṭho hoti, goṇo hoti, gadrabho hoti, sūkaro hoti, mahiṁso hotīti?
analyzed: atthi koci manussaḥ hutvā yakkhaḥ hoti petaḥ hoti nerayikaḥ hoti tiracchāna gataḥ hoti oṭṭhaḥ hoti goṇaḥ hoti gadrabhaḥ hoti sūkaraḥ hoti mahisaḥ hoti iti
translated: Is there any human being who becomes a spirit, a ghost, a denizen of hell, an animal, a camel, an ox, an ass, a pig, or a bird?
“Yes.”

analyzed: su eva manussaḥ saḥ mahisaḥ iti
translated: “Is that human being the same as that bird?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the abandoning of lust, the abandoning of hatred, the abandoning of delusion?

analyzed: su eva manussaḥ saḥ mahisaḥ iti
translated: “Is that human being the same as that bird?”
“Yes.”

original: Manusso hutvā mahiṁso hoti, mahiṁso hutvā manusso hoti, manussabhūto añño, mahiṁso añño, manussabhūto svevāyaṁ sandhāvatīti micchā …pe….
analyzed: manussaḥ hutvā mahisaḥ hoti mahisaḥ hutvā manussaḥ hoti manussa bhūtaḥ aññaḥ mahisaḥ aññaḥ manussa bhūtaḥ su eva ayam sandhāvati iti micchā pe
translated: “It is wrong to say that a human being becomes a bird, that a bird becomes a human being, that a human being and a bird are the same, and that a human being transmigrates.”

original: Sace hi sandhāvati sveva puggalo ito cuto paraṁ lokaṁ anañño, hevaṁ maraṇaṁ na hehiti, pāṇātipātopi nupalabbhati.
analyzed: sace hi sandhāvati su eva puggalaḥ itas cutas param lokam anaññaḥ ha ivam maraṇam na pāṇa atipātaḥ api na upalabbhati
translated: If a person transmigrates from this world to the next, and is not different, then killing would not be found.

original: Kammaṁ atthi, kammavipāko atthi, katānaṁ kammānaṁ vipāko atthi, kusalākusale vipaccamāne svevāyaṁ sandhāvatīti micchā.
analyzed: kammam atthi kamma vipākaḥ atthi katānam kammānam vipākaḥ atthi kusala akusale vipaccamāne su eva ayam sandhāvati iti micchā
translated: It is wrong to say that there is action, there is result, there is action and result, and that a person transmigrates when wholesome and unwholesome actions are being experienced.

original: Sveva puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: su eva puggalaḥ sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: “Does that person transmigrate from this world to the next, and from the next world to this world?”
“Yes.”

original: Atthi koci khattiyo hutvā brāhmaṇo hotīti?
analyzed: atthi koci khattiyaḥ hutvā brāhmaṇaḥ hoti iti
translated: “Is there any warrior who becomes a brahmin?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: su eva khattiyaḥ saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ iti
translated: “Is that warrior the same as the brahmin?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the abandoning of lust, the abandoning of hatred, the abandoning of delusion?

original: Atthi koci khattiyo hutvā vesso hoti, suddo hotīti?
analyzed: atthi koci khattiyaḥ hutvā vessaḥ hoti suddaḥ hoti iti
translated: “Is there any warrior who becomes a merchant or an artisan or a worker?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: su eva khattiyaḥ saḥ suddo ti
translated: “Is that warrior the same as the worker?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: Atthi koci brāhmaṇo hutvā vesso hoti, suddo hoti, khattiyo hotīti?
analyzed: atthi koci brāhmaṇaḥ hutvā vessaḥ hoti suddaḥ hoti khattiyaḥ hoti iti
translated: “Is there any brahmin who becomes a merchant or an artisan or a worker or a warrior?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: su eva brāhmaṇaḥ saḥ khattiyaḥ iti
translated: “Is that brahmin the same as the warrior?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: Atthi koci vesso hutvā suddo hoti, khattiyo hoti, brāhmaṇo hotīti?
analyzed: atthi koci vessaḥ hutvā suddaḥ hoti khattiyaḥ hoti brāhmaṇaḥ hoti iti
translated: “Is there any merchant who becomes an artisan or a worker or a warrior or a brahmin?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: su eva vessaḥ saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ iti
translated: “Is that merchant the same as the brahmin?”
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye faculty and the eye consciousness?” …

original: Atthi koci suddo hutvā khattiyo hoti, brāhmaṇo hoti, vesso hotīti?
analyzed: atthi koci suddaḥ hutvā khattiyaḥ hoti brāhmaṇaḥ hoti vessaḥ hoti iti
translated: “Is there any worker who becomes a warrior or a brahmin or a merchant or an artisan?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: su eva suddaḥ saḥ vessaḥ ti
translated: “Is that worker the same as the artisan?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: Sveva puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: su eva puggalaḥ sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: “Does that same person wander on and on, transmigrating through this realm of existence from this world to the next?”
“Yes.”

original: Hatthacchinno hatthacchinnova hoti, pādacchinno pādacchinnova hoti, hatthapādacchinno
analyzed: hattha chinnaḥ hattha chinnaḥ uva hoti pāda chinnaḥ pāda chinnaḥ uva hoti hattha pāda chinnaḥ
translated: One who is a handless person is a handless person, one who is a footless person is a footless person, one who is a handless-footless person is a handless-footless person,🔽one who is an earless person … one who is a noseless person … one who is an earless-noseless person … one who is a fingerless person …

original: hatthapādacchinnova hoti, kaṇṇacchinno … nāsacchinno … kaṇṇanāsacchinno … aṅgulicchinno🔽… aḷacchinno … kaṇḍaracchinno … kuṇihatthako … phaṇahatthako … kuṭṭhiyo … gaṇḍiyo🔽… kilāsiyo … sosiyo … apamāriyo … oṭṭho … goṇo … gadrabho … sūkaro … mahiṁso mahiṁsova hotīti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe….🔽Na vattabbaṁ—
analyzed: hattha pāda chinnaḥ uva hoti kaṇṇa chinnaḥ nāsa chinnaḥ kaṇṇa nāsa chinnaḥ aṅguli chinno  aḷacchinno kaṇḍaracchinno kuṇihatthako phaṇahatthako kuṭṭhiyaḥ gaṇḍiyo  kilāsiyaḥ sosiyaḥ apamāriyaḥ oṭṭhaḥ goṇaḥ gadrabhaḥ sūkaraḥ mahisaḥ mahisā uva hoti iti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe  na vattabba
translated: one who is a toeless person … one who is a fingerless-toeless person … one who is a one-eyed person … one who is a squint-eyed person … one who is a leper … one who is a leper with sores …

original: “sveva puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokan”ti?🔽Āmantā.🔽Nanu sotāpanno puggalo manussalokā cuto devalokaṁ upapanno tatthapi sotāpannova hotīti?🔽Āmantā.🔽Hañci sotāpanno puggalo manussalokā cuto devalokaṁ upapanno tatthapi sotāpannova hoti, tena vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: su eva puggalaḥ sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam 🔽āmantā 🔽nanu sotāpannaḥ puggalaḥ manussa lokā cutaḥ deva lokam upapanno tattha api sotāpannaḥ va hoti iti 🔽āmantā 🔽hañci sotāpannaḥ puggalaḥ manussa lokā cutaḥ deva lokam upapanno tattha api sotāpannaḥ va hoti tena vata re vattabbe
translated: one who is a leper with blisters … one who is a leper with blotches … one who is a dropsy person … one who is a consumptive person … one who is an epileptic person … one who is a person with haemorrhoids … one who is a goitre person … one who is a club-foot person … one who is a cripple … one who is a lame person … one who is a paralysed person … one who is a hunchback … one who is a dwarf … one who is a eunuch … one who is a neuter person … one who is a woman … one who is a man … one who is a bull … one who is an ox … one who is a donkey … one who is a pig … one who is a goose … one who is a swan … one who is a peacock … one who is a cock … one who is a dog … one who is a jackal … one who is a hyena … one who is a lion … one who is a tiger … one who is a leopard … one who is a bear … one who is a snake … one who is a python … one who is a crocodile … one who is a fish … one who is a tortoise … one who is a shrimp … one who is a crab … one who is a worm … one who is an insect … one who is a moth … one who is a bird … one who is a deer … one who is a wild animal … one who is a monkey … one who is a human … one who is a ghost … one who is a spirit … one who is a demon … one who is a serpent … one who is a god … one who is a Brahma … one who is a person of the lowest caste … one who is a person of mixed caste … one who is a person of the lowest

original: “sveva puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokan”ti.
analyzed: su eva puggalaḥ sandhāvati asmai lokā param parasmai lokā imam
translated: “That same person moves on from this world to the next world, and from the next world to this world.”

original: Sotāpanno puggalo manussalokā cuto devalokaṁ upapanno tatthapi sotāpannova hotīti katvā tena ca kāraṇena sveva puggalo sandhāvati asmā lokā paraṁ lokaṁ, parasmā lokā imaṁ lokanti?
analyzed: sotāpanno puggalo manussa lokā cutaḥ deva lokam upapanno tattha api sotāpannaḥ va hoti iti katvā tena ca kāraṇena su eva puggalo sandhāvati asmai lokā param loka parasmai lokā imam lokanti
translated: “Is it because a stream-enterer, having passed away as a human being and been reborn in the realm of the gods, is still a stream-enterer there that you say, ‘That same person moves on from this world to the next world, and from the next world to this world’?”
The Invitation Ceremony.

original: Sotāpanno puggalo manussalokā cuto devalokaṁ upapanno tatthapi manusso hotīti katvā?

Is a person described by referring to material form?
Yes.

original: Rūpaṁ aniccaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ khayadhammaṁ vayadhammaṁ virāgadhammaṁ nirodhadhammaṁ vipariṇāmadhammanti?
analyzed: rūpam aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam khaya dhammam vaya dhammam virāga dhammam nirodha dhammam vipariṇāma dhammanti
translated: Is material form impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change?
Yes.

original: Puggalopi anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno khayadhammo vayadhammo virāgadhammo nirodhadhammo vipariṇāmadhammoti?
analyzed: puggalaḥ api aniccaḥ saṅkhataḥ paṭicca samuppanno khaya dhammo vaya dhammo virāga dhammo nirodha dhammo vipariṇāma dhammo ti
translated: Is a person impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change?
You may not say that.

original: Vedanaṁ upādāya … saññaṁ upādāya … saṅkhāre upādāya … viññāṇaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: vedanam upādāya saññam upādāya saṅkhāre upādāya viññāṇam upādāya puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: Is a person described by referring to feeling … by referring to perception … by referring to volitional formations … by referring to consciousness?
Yes.

original: Viññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ khayadhammaṁ vayadhammaṁ virāgadhammaṁ nirodhadhammaṁ vipariṇāmadhammanti?
analyzed: viññāṇam aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam khaya dhammam vaya dhammam virāga dhammam nirodha dhammam vipariṇāma dhamman ti

Yes.

original: Puggalopi anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno khayadhammo vayadhammo virāgadhammo nirodhadhammo vipariṇāmadhammoti?
analyzed: puggalaḥ api aniccaḥ saṅkhataḥ paṭicca samuppanno khaya dhammo vaya dhammo virāga dhammo nirodha dhammo vipariṇāma dhammo ti
translated: Is a person impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change?
You may not say that.
“Is a person described by assuming material form?”
The Invitation Ceremony.

original: Nīlaṁ rūpaṁ upādāya nīlakassa puggalassa paññattīti?

“Is a person described by assuming feeling?”
The Invitation Ceremony.

original: Kusalaṁ vedanaṁ upādāya kusalassa puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: kusalam vedanam upādāya kusalassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Is a person described by assuming wholesome feeling?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: kusalaṁ vedanaṁ upādāya kusalassa puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: kusalam vedanam upādāya kusalassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Is a person described by assuming wholesome feeling?”
The Invitation Ceremony.

original: Kusalā vedanā saphalā savipākā iṭṭhaphalā kantaphalā manuññaphalā asecanakaphalā sukhudrayā sukhavipākāti?
analyzed: kusalā vedanā sa phalā sa vipākā iṭṭha phalā kanta phalā manuñña phalā asecanaka phalā su khudrayā sukha vipākā ati
translated: “Is wholesome feeling with result and ripening, with pleasant result, agreeable result, desirable result, not resulting in suffering?”
The Invitation Ceremony.

original: Kusalopi puggalo saphalo savipāko iṭṭhaphalo kantaphalo manuññaphalo asecanakaphalo sukhudrayo sukhavipākoti?
analyzed: kusalo api puggalo sa phalo sa vipāko iṭṭha phalo kanta phalo manuñña phalo asecanaka phalo su khudrayo sukha vipāko ti
translated: Is a profitable person fruitful, with results, having desirable, agreeable, and pleasant results, with happiness as its outcome and happiness as its result?
You say “No”…
Is a person described by referring to feeling?
Yes.

original: Akusalaṁ vedanaṁ upādāya akusalassa puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: akusalam vedanam upādāya akusalassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: Is an unprofitable person described by referring to unprofitable feeling?
You say “No”…

original: akusalaṁ vedanaṁ upādāya akusalassa puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: akusalam vedanam upādāya akusalassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: Is an unprofitable person described by referring to unprofitable feeling?
Yes.

original: Akusalā vedanā saphalā savipākā aniṭṭhaphalā akantaphalā amanuññaphalā secanakaphalā dukkhudrayā dukkhavipākāti?
analyzed: akusalā vedanā sa phalā sa vipākā aniṭṭha phalā akanta phalā amanuñña phalā secanaka phalā dukkhudrayā dukkha vipākā ati
translated: Are unprofitable feelings fruitful, with results, having undesirable, disagreeable, and unpleasant results, with suffering as their outcome and suffering as their result?
Yes.

original: Akusalopi puggalo saphalo savipāko aniṭṭhaphalo akantaphalo amanuññaphalo secanakaphalo dukkhudrayo dukkhavipākoti?
analyzed: akusalaḥ pi puggalo sa phalaḥ sa vipākaḥ aniṭṭha phalaḥ a kanta phalaḥ a manuñña phalo secanaka phalaḥ dukkhudrayaḥ dukkha vipāko ti
translated: Is an unprofitable person fruitful, with results, having undesirable, disagreeable, and unpleasant results, with suffering as its outcome and suffering as its result?
You say “No”…
Is a person described by referring to feeling?
Yes.

original: Abyākataṁ vedanaṁ upādāya abyākatassa puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: abyākatam vedanam upādāya abyākatassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: Is an indeterminate person described by referring to indeterminate feeling?
“That can’t be said.”

original: abyākataṁ vedanaṁ upādāya abyākatassa puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: abyākatam vedanam upādāya abyākatassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Is the designation of a person as ‘unspecified’ dependent on unspecified feeling?”
“Yes.”

original: Abyākatā vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā vipariṇāmadhammāti?
analyzed: abyākatā vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭicca samuppannā khaya dhammā vaya dhammā virāga dhammā nirodha dhammā vipariṇāma dhammā ati
translated: “Are unspecified feelings impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change?”
“Yes.”

original: Abyākatopi puggalo anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno khayadhammo vayadhammo virāgadhammo nirodhadhammo vipariṇāmadhammoti?
analyzed: abyākataḥ api puggalo aniccaḥ saṅkhataḥ paṭicca samuppanno khaya dhammo vaya dhammo virāga dhammo nirodha dhammo vipariṇāma dhammo ti
translated: “Is a person as ‘unspecified’ impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change?”
“That can’t be said.”

original: Saññaṁ upādāya … saṅkhāre upādāya … viññāṇaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: saññam upādāya saṅkhāre upādāya viññāṇam upādāya puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Is the designation of a person dependent on perception … dependent on mental formations … dependent on consciousness?”
“Yes.”

original: Kusalaṁ viññāṇaṁ upādāya kusalassa puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: kusalam viññāṇam upādāya kusalassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Is the designation of a person as ‘wholesome’ dependent on wholesome consciousness?”
“That can’t be said.”

original: kusalaṁ viññāṇaṁ upādāya kusalassa puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: kusalam viññāṇam upādāya kusalassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Is the designation of a person as ‘wholesome’ dependent on wholesome consciousness?”
“Yes.”

original: Kusalaṁ viññāṇaṁ saphalaṁ savipākaṁ iṭṭhaphalaṁ kantaphalaṁ manuññaphalaṁ asecanakaphalaṁ sukhudrayaṁ sukhavipākanti?
analyzed: kusalam viññāṇam sa phalam sa vipākam iṭṭha phalam kanta phalam manuñña phalam asecanaka phalam su khudrayam sukha vipākam ti
translated: Is profitable consciousness fruitful, with a result, having a desirable result, a pleasant result, a lovely result, not a repellent result, with happiness as its outcome, ripening in happiness?
Agreed.

original: Kusalopi puggalo saphalo savipāko iṭṭhaphalo kantaphalo manuññaphalo asecanakaphalo sukhudrayo sukhavipākoti?
analyzed: kusalo api puggalo sa phalo sa vipāko iṭṭha phalo kanta phalo manuñña phalo asecanaka phalo su khudrayo sukha vipāko ti
translated: Is a profitable person fruitful, with a result, having a desirable result, a pleasant result, a lovely result, not a repellent result, with happiness as his outcome, ripening in happiness?
You say “No.” …
Is a person described by consciousness?
Agreed.

original: Akusalaṁ viññāṇaṁ upādāya akusalassa puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: akusalam viññāṇam upādāya akusalassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: Is a unprofitable person described by unprofitable consciousness?
You say “No.” …

original: akusalaṁ viññāṇaṁ upādāya akusalassa puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: akusalam viññāṇam upādāya akusalassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: Is a unprofitable person described by unprofitable consciousness?
Agreed.

original: Akusalaṁ viññāṇaṁ saphalaṁ savipākaṁ aniṭṭhaphalaṁ akantaphalaṁ amanuññaphalaṁ secanakaphalaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākanti?
analyzed: akusalam viññāṇam sa phalam sa vipākam aniṭṭha phalam a kanta phalam a manuñña phalam secanaka phalam dukkhudrayam dukkha vipākam ti
translated: Is unprofitable consciousness fruitful, with a result, having an undesirable result, an unpleasant result, an unlovely result, a repellent result, with suffering as its outcome, ripening in suffering?
Agreed.

original: Akusalopi puggalo saphalo savipāko aniṭṭhaphalo akantaphalo amanuññaphalo secanakaphalo dukkhudrayo dukkhavipākoti?
analyzed: akusalaḥ pi puggalo sa phalaḥ sa vipākaḥ aniṭṭha phalaḥ a kanta phalaḥ a manuñña phalo secanaka phalaḥ dukkhudrayaḥ dukkha vipāko ti
translated: Is an unwholesome person fruitful, with results, having a result, having results, having a result that is unliked, having a result that is undesirable, having a result that is disagreeable, having a result that is unpleasant, having a result that is painful, having a result that is suffering?”
“No,” he replied.
“Is a person described by reference to consciousness?”
“Yes.”

original: Abyākataṁ viññāṇaṁ upādāya abyākatassa puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: abyākatam viññāṇam upādāya abyākatassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Is an indeterminate person described by reference to indeterminate consciousness?”
“No,” he replied.

original: abyākataṁ viññāṇaṁ upādāya abyākatassa puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: abyākatam viññāṇam upādāya abyākatassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Is an indeterminate person described by reference to indeterminate consciousness?”
“Yes.”

original: Abyākataṁ viññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ khayadhammaṁ vayadhammaṁ virāgadhammaṁ nirodhadhammaṁ vipariṇāmadhammanti?
analyzed: abyākatam viññāṇam aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam khaya dhammam vaya dhammam virāga dhammam nirodha dhammam vipariṇāma dhammanti
translated: “Is indeterminate consciousness impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change?”
“Yes.”

original: Abyākatopi puggalo anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno khayadhammo vayadhammo virāgadhammo nirodhadhammo vipariṇāmadhammoti?
analyzed: abyākataḥ api puggalo aniccaḥ saṅkhataḥ paṭicca samuppanno khaya dhammo vaya dhammo virāga dhammo nirodha dhammo vipariṇāma dhammo ti
translated: “Is an indeterminate person impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change?”
“No,” he replied.

analyzed: cakkhum upādāya cakkhumā puggalaḥ iti vattabbaḥ ti
translated: “Is a person who has eyes to be called ‘one who has eyes’?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: cakkhumhi niruddhe cakkhumā puggalo niruddho ti vattabbaḥ ti
translated: When the eye has ceased, should it be said that a person with vision has ceased?
You say it should not be so said.

original: sotaṁ upādāya … ghānaṁ upādāya … jivhaṁ upādāya … kāyaṁ upādāya … manaṁ upādāya “manavā puggalo”ti vattabboti?🔽Āmantā.
analyzed: sotam upādāya ghānam upādāya jivham upādāya kāyam upādāya manam upādāya manavā puggalaḥ iti vattabbaḥ ti  āmantā
translated: On the basis of the ear … the nose … the tongue … the body … the mind, should it be said that a person with a mind exists?🔽You say it should not be so said.

analyzed: manamhi niruddhe manavā puggalaḥ niruddho ti vattabbo ti
translated: When the mind has ceased, should it be said that a person with a mind has ceased?
You say it should not be so said.

analyzed: micchādiṭṭhim upādāya micchādiṭṭhiyaḥ puggalaḥ ti vattabbaḥ ti  āmantā
translated: On the basis of wrong view, should it be said that a person with wrong view exists?🔽You say it should not be so said.

analyzed: micchādiṭṭhiyā niruddhāya micchādiṭṭhiyaḥ puggalo niruddho ti vattabbaḥ ti
translated: When wrong view has ceased, should it be said that a person with wrong view has ceased?

original: Na hevaṁ vattabbe.🔽Micchāsaṅkappaṁ upādāya … micchāvācaṁ upādāya … micchākammantaṁ upādāya … micchāājīvaṁ
analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe  micchā saṅkappam upādāya micchā vācam upādāya micchā kammantam upādāya micchā ājīva
translated: You say it should not be so said.

original: upādāya … micchāvāyāmaṁ upādāya … micchāsatiṁ upādāya … micchāsamādhiṁ upādāya “micchāsamādhiyo🔽puggalo”ti vattabboti?
analyzed: upādāya micchāvāyāmam upādāya micchā satim upādāya micchā samādhim upādāya  puggalaḥ iti vattabbaḥ ti
translated: On the basis of wrong thought … wrong speech … wrong action … wrong livelihood … wrong effort … wrong mindfulness … wrong concentration, should it be said that a person with wrong concentration exists?
You say it should not be so said.

analyzed: micchāsamādhimhi niruddhe micchāsamādhiyo puggalo niruddho ti vattabbaḥ ti
translated: When wrong concentration has ceased, should it be said that a person with wrong concentration has ceased?
… ‘He should not say so.’

analyzed: sammādiṭṭhim upādāya sammādiṭṭhiyaḥ puggalaḥ ti vattabbaḥ ti
translated: ‘Should it be said that a person with right view exists by clinging to right view?’
… ‘He should say so.’

analyzed: sammādiṭṭhiyā niruddhāya sammādiṭṭhiyo puggalo niruddho ti vattabbaḥ ti
translated: ‘When right view has ceased, should it be said that a person with right view has ceased?’

original: Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe…🔽sammāsaṅkappaṁ upādāya … sammāvācaṁ upādāya … sammākammantaṁ upādāya … sammāājīvaṁ🔽upādāya … sammāvāyāmaṁ upādāya … sammāsatiṁ upādāya … sammāsamādhiṁ upādāya “sammāsamādhiyo
analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe pe  sammā saṅkappam upādāya sammā vācam upādāya sammā kammantam upādāya sammā ājīva  upādāya sammā vāyāmam upādāya sammā satim upādāya sammā samādhim upādāya sammā samādhiyo
translated: … ‘He should not say so.’🔽‘Should it be said that a person with right intention … with right speech … with right action … with right livelihood … with right effort … with right mindfulness … with right concentration exists by clinging to right concentration?’
… ‘He should say so.’

analyzed: sammāsamādhimhi niruddhe sammāsamādhiyo puggalo niruddho ti vattabbaḥ ti
translated: ‘When right concentration has ceased, should it be said that a person with right concentration has ceased?’
… ‘He should not say so.’

original: Rūpaṁ upādāya, vedanaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: rūpam upādāya vedanam upādāya puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: ‘Is a person described by reference to form and by reference to feeling?’
… ‘He should say so.’

original: Dvinnaṁ khandhānaṁ upādāya dvinnaṁ puggalānaṁ paññattīti?
analyzed: dvinnam khandhānam upādāya dvinnam puggalānam paññatti iti
translated: ‘Are two persons described by reference to two aggregates?’
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: rūpaṁ upādāya, vedanaṁ upādāya, saññaṁ upādāya, saṅkhāre upādāya, viññāṇaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: rūpam upādāya vedanam upādāya saññam upādāya saṅkhāre upādāya viññāṇam upādāya puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Then is it because of form, because of feeling, because of perception, because of formations, because of consciousness that the designation of a person comes about?”
“Yes.”

original: Pañcannaṁ khandhānaṁ upādāya pañcannaṁ puggalānaṁ paññattīti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe….
analyzed: pañcannam khandhānam upādāya pañcannam puggalānam paññatti iti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: “Is it because of the five aggregates that the designation of the five kinds of persons comes about?”

original: Cakkhāyatanaṁ upādāya, sotāyatanaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: cakkhu āyatanam upādāya sota āyatanam upādāya puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Then is it because of the eye faculty that the designation of a person comes about?”
“Yes.”

original: Dvinnaṁ āyatanānaṁ upādāya dvinnaṁ puggalānaṁ paññattīti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe…
analyzed: dvinnam āyatanānam upādāya dvinnam puggalānam paññatti iti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: “Is it because of the two faculties that the designation of the two kinds of persons comes about?”
“Then is it because of the eye faculty and the ear faculty …
because of the mind faculty and the idea faculty that the designation of a person comes about?”
“Yes.”

original: Dvādasannaṁ āyatanānaṁ upādāya dvādasannaṁ puggalānaṁ paññattīti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe….
analyzed: dvādasannam āyatanānam upādāya dvādasannam puggalānam paññatti iti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: “Is it because of the twelve faculties that the designation of the twelve kinds of persons comes about?”

original: Cakkhudhātuṁ upādāya, sotadhātuṁ upādāya puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: cakkhu dhātum upādāya sota dhātum upādāya puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Then is it because of the eye element that the designation of a person comes about?”
“Yes.”

original: Dvinnaṁ dhātūnaṁ upādāya dvinnaṁ puggalānaṁ paññattīti?
analyzed: dvinnam dhātūnam upādāya dvinnam puggalānam paññatti iti
translated: “Is it because of the two elements that the designation of the two kinds of persons comes about?”

original: Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe…🔽cakkhudhātuṁ upādāya, sotadhātuṁ upādāya …pe…
analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe pe  cakkhu dhātum upādāya sota dhātum upādāya pe
translated: “That can’t be said.”🔽“Is the designation of a person made dependent on the eye element, the ear element …
the mind element, the mental-data element?”
“Yes.”

original: Aṭṭhārasannaṁ dhātūnaṁ upādāya aṭṭhārasannaṁ puggalānaṁ paññattīti?
analyzed: aṭṭhārasannam dhātūnam upādāya aṭṭhārasannam puggalānam paññatti iti
translated: “Is the designation of eighteen kinds of persons made dependent on the eighteen elements?”
“That can’t be said.”

original: Cakkhundriyaṁ upādāya, sotindriyaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: cakkhu indriyam upādāya sotindriyam upādāya puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Is the designation of a person made dependent on the eye faculty, the ear faculty?”
“Yes.”

original: Dvinnaṁ indriyānaṁ upādāya dvinnaṁ puggalānaṁ paññattīti?
analyzed: dvinnam indriyānam upādāya dvinnam puggalānam paññatti iti
translated: “Is the designation of two kinds of persons made dependent on the two faculties?”

original: Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe…🔽cakkhundriyaṁ upādāya, sotindriyaṁ upādāya …pe…
analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe pe  cakkhu indriyam upādāya sotindriyam upādāya pe
translated: “That can’t be said.”🔽“Is the designation of a person made dependent on the eye faculty, the ear faculty …
the final-knower faculty?”
“Yes.”

original: Bāvīsatīnaṁ indriyānaṁ upādāya bāvīsatīnaṁ puggalānaṁ paññattīti?
analyzed: bāvīsatīnam indriyānam upādāya bāvīsatīnam puggalānam paññatti iti
translated: “Is the designation of twenty-two kinds of persons made dependent on the twenty-two faculties?”
“That can’t be said.”

analyzed: ekavokāra bhavam upādāya ekassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Is the designation of a person made dependent on a single-constituent becoming?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: catuvokāra bhavam upādāya catunnam puggalānam paññatti iti
translated: “Is the designation of four kinds of persons made dependent on a four-constituent becoming?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: ekavokāra bhavam upādāya ekassa puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Then is it because of a single-constituent existence that a single person is conceived?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: pañcavokāra bhavam upādāya pañcannam puggalānam paññatti iti
translated: “Is it because of a five-constituent existence that five persons are conceived?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: ekavokāra bhave ekaḥ iva puggalo ti
translated: “Then is it because of a single-constituent existence that a single person is conceived?”
“Yes.”
“Is it because of a four-constituent existence that four persons are conceived?”
“Is it so that one who is not a trainee is not a person who has entered upon the way?” …

analyzed: ekavokāra bhave ekaḥ iva puggalo ti
translated: “Then is it because of a single-constituent existence that a single person is conceived?”
“Yes.”
“Is it because of a five-constituent existence that five persons are conceived?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the abandoning of lust, the abandoning of hatred, the abandoning of delusion?

original: Yathā rukkhaṁ upādāya chāyāya paññatti, evamevaṁ rūpaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: yathā rukkham upādāya chāyāya paññatti evam evam rūpam upādāya puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: “Is it as there is a conception of shade because of a tree, so too, is there a conception of a person because of form?”

original: (…) Yathā rukkhaṁ upādāya chāyāya paññatti, rukkhopi anicco chāyāpi aniccā, evamevaṁ rūpaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññatti, rūpampi aniccaṁ puggalopi aniccoti?
analyzed: yathā rukkham upādāya chāyāya paññatti rukkhaḥ api aniccaḥ chāyā api aniccā evam evam rūpam upādāya puggalassa paññatti rūpam pi aniccam puggalaḥ api aniccaḥ ti
translated: “Is it as there is a conception of shade because of a tree, and the tree is impermanent and the shade is impermanent, so too, is there a conception of a person because of form, and form is impermanent and the person is impermanent?”

“No.”🔽“Is it as there is a conception of shade because of a tree, and the tree is impermanent and the shade is impermanent, so too, is there a conception of a person because of feeling … because of perception … because of volitional formations … because of consciousness, and consciousness is impermanent and the person is impermanent?”

original: yathā rukkhaṁ upādāya chāyāya paññatti, añño rukkho aññā chāyā, evamevaṁ rūpaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññatti, aññaṁ rūpaṁ añño puggaloti?
analyzed: yathā rukkham upādāya chāyāya paññatti aññaḥ rukkhaḥ aññā chāyā evam evam rūpam upādāya puggalassa paññatti aññam rūpam aññaḥ puggalaḥ ti
translated: Is it that, just as the designation ‘shade’ is dependent on the tree, the tree being one thing and the shade another, so too the designation of a person is dependent on material form, the material form being one thing and the person another?
You have gone too far.

original: Yathā gāmaṁ upādāya gāmikassa paññatti, evamevaṁ rūpaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: yathā gāmam upādāya gāmikassa paññatti evam evam rūpam upādāya puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: Is it that, just as the designation ‘villager’ is dependent on the village, so too the designation of a person is dependent on material form?

original: Yathā gāmaṁ upādāya gāmikassa paññatti, añño gāmo añño gāmiko, evamevaṁ rūpaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññatti, aññaṁ rūpaṁ añño puggaloti?
analyzed: yathā gāmam upādāya gāmikassa paññatti aññaḥ gāmaḥ aññaḥ gāmikaḥ evam evam rūpam upādāya puggalassa paññatti aññam rūpam aññaḥ puggalaḥ ti
translated: Is it that, just as the designation ‘villager’ is dependent on the village, the village being one thing and the villager another, so too the designation of a person is dependent on material form, the material form being one thing and the person another?
You have gone too far.

original: Yathā raṭṭhaṁ upādāya rañño paññatti, evamevaṁ rūpaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññattīti?
analyzed: yathā raṭṭham upādāya raññaḥ paññatti evam evam rūpam upādāya puggalassa paññatti iti
translated: Is it that, just as the designation ‘king’ is dependent on the kingdom, so too the designation of a person is dependent on material form?

original: Yathā raṭṭhaṁ upādāya rañño paññatti, aññaṁ raṭṭhaṁ añño rājā, evamevaṁ rūpaṁ upādāya puggalassa paññatti, aññaṁ rūpaṁ añño puggaloti?
analyzed: yathā raṭṭham upādāya raññaḥ paññatti aññam raṭṭham aññaḥ rājā evam evam rūpam upādāya puggalassa paññatti aññam rūpam aññaḥ puggalaḥ ti
translated: Is it that, just as the designation ‘king’ is dependent on the kingdom, the kingdom being one thing and the king another, so too the designation of a person is dependent on material form, the material form being one thing and the person another?
You have gone too far.

original: Yathā na nigaḷo negaḷiko, yassa nigaḷo so negaḷiko, evamevaṁ na rūpaṁ rūpavā, yassa rūpaṁ so rūpavāti?
analyzed: yathā na nigaḷaḥ negaḷikaḥ yassa nigaḷaḥ saḥ negaḷikaḥ evam evam na rūpam rūpavā yassa rūpam saḥ rūpavā ati
translated: Is it not the case that one who is not bound is not one who is bound, and that one who is bound is not one who is not bound?

original: Yathā na nigaḷo negaḷiko, yassa nigaḷo so negaḷiko, añño nigaḷo añño negaḷiko, evamevaṁ na rūpaṁ rūpavā, yassa rūpaṁ so rūpavā, aññaṁ rūpaṁ añño rūpavāti?
analyzed: yathā na nigaḷaḥ negaḷikaḥ yassa nigaḷaḥ so negaḷikaḥ aññaḥ nigaḷaḥ aññaḥ negaḷikaḥ evam evam na rūpam rūpavā yassa rūpam saḥ rūpavā aññam rūpam aññaḥ rūpavā ati
translated: Is it not the case that one who is not bound is not one who is bound, and that one who is bound is not one who is not bound, and that one who is not bound is different from one who is bound, and that one who is bound is different from one who is not bound?
You say: “No.”
Is a person ascribed to each consciousness?
“Yes.”

original: Citte citte puggalo jāyati jīyati mīyati cavati upapajjatīti?
analyzed: citte citte puggalaḥ jāyati jīyati mīyati cavati upapajjati iti
translated: Is a person born, ages, dies, falls away, and reappears in each consciousness?
You say: “No.”

original: dutiye citte uppanne na vattabbaṁ soti vā aññoti vāti?
analyzed: dutiye citte uppanne na vattabbam saḥ ti vā aññaḥ ti vā ati
translated: When the second consciousness arises, is it not the same one or a different one?
“Yes.”

original: Dutiye citte uppanne na vattabbaṁ kumārakoti vā kumārikāti vāti?
analyzed: dutiye citte uppanne na vattabbam kumārako iti vā kumārikā ati vā ati
translated: When the second consciousness arises, is it not a boy or a girl?
“Yes.”🔽You are refuted.

original: Ājānāhi niggahaṁ.🔽Hañci dutiye citte uppanne na vattabbaṁ—
analyzed: ājānāhi niggaha  hañci dutiye citte uppanne na vattabba
translated: You are caught in contradiction.🔽You have accepted the refutation.

original: “soti vā aññoti vā”, tena vata re vattabbe—🔽“dutiye citte uppanne na vattabbaṁ—
analyzed: saḥ ti vā aññaḥ ti vā tena vata re vattabbe 🔽dutiye citte uppanne na vattabba
translated: You have been refuted.🔽You have been caught in contradiction.🔽You have accepted the refutation.

analyzed: kumārakā uti vā kumārikā ati vā ati  yam tattha vadesi
translated: What do you think?
“It should be said
that when the second consciousness arises, it shouldn’t be said

original: soti vā aññoti vā, dutiye citte uppanne vattabbaṁ—
analyzed: saḥ ti vā aññaḥ ti vā dutiye citte uppanne vattabba
translated: that ‘he’ or ‘another’ exists. When the second consciousness arises, it should be said

analyzed: kumārakā uti vā kumārikā ati vā ati micchā
translated: that ‘a boy’ or ‘a girl’ exists.”

original: Hañci vā pana dutiye citte uppanne vattabbaṁ—
analyzed: hañci vā pana dutiye citte uppanne vattabba
translated: “But if, when the second consciousness arises,

original: “kumārakoti vā kumārikā”ti vā, tena vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: kumārakā iti vā kumārikā ati vā tena vata re vattabbe

then it should be said that when the second consciousness arises,

analyzed: saḥ ti vā añño ti vā ati
translated: it should be said that ‘he’ or ‘another’ exists.”
What do you think?
“It should be said
that when the second consciousness arises, it shouldn’t be said

original: soti vā aññoti vā, dutiye citte uppanne vattabbaṁ—
analyzed: saḥ ti vā aññaḥ ti vā dutiye citte uppanne vattabba
translated: that ‘he’ or ‘another’ exists. When the second consciousness arises, it should be said🔽that ‘a boy’ or ‘a girl’ exists.”🔽“But if, when the second consciousness arises,🔽it should be said that ‘a boy’ or ‘a girl’ exists,🔽then it should be said that when the second consciousness arises,

analyzed: kumārakā uti vā kumārikā ati vā ati micchā
translated: it should be said that ‘he’ or ‘another’ exists.”
“When the second consciousness arises, should it not be said

analyzed: saḥ ti vā añño ti vā ati
translated: that ‘he’ or ‘another’ exists?”
“Yes.”
“When the second consciousness arises, should it not be said🔽that ‘a woman’ or ‘a man,’ ‘a householder’ or ‘one gone forth,’ ‘a god’ or ‘a human’ exists?”

original: “itthīti vā purisoti vā gahaṭṭhoti vā pabbajitoti vā devoti vā manussoti vā”ti?
analyzed: itthī iti vā purisaḥ iti vā gahaṭṭho ti vā pabbajitoti vā devaḥ iti vā manussoti vā ati
translated: “Yes.”
You should say:
‘You’re refuted.’

original: Hañci dutiye citte uppanne na vattabbaṁ—
analyzed: hañci dutiye citte uppanne na vattabba
translated: If you say, ‘When the second consciousness has arisen, it shouldn’t be said

original: “soti vā aññoti vā”, tena vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: saḥ ti vā aññaḥ ti vā tena vata re vattabbe
translated: that it’s the same or different,’ then you should also say
that when the second consciousness has arisen, it shouldn’t be said

analyzed: devaḥ ti vā manusso ti vā ati
translated: that it’s a god or a human.’🔽And so,
you shouldn’t say
that when the second consciousness has arisen, it shouldn’t be said🔽that it’s the same or different,

analyzed: hañci vā pana dutiye citte uppanne vattabba

translated: that it’s a god or a human,’ then you should also say
that when the second consciousness has arisen, it should be said

translated: that it’s the same or different.’🔽And so,
you shouldn’t say
that when the second consciousness has arisen, it shouldn’t be said🔽that it’s the same or different,

original: soti vā aññoti vā, dutiye citte uppanne vattabbaṁ—
analyzed: saḥ ti vā aññaḥ ti vā dutiye citte uppanne vattabba
translated: but that when the second consciousness has arisen, it should be said

analyzed: devaḥ ti vā manusso ti vā ati micchā pe
translated: that it’s a god or a human.’
You shouldn’t say,
“Is a person found in a real and ultimate way?”
“Yes.”

original: Nanu yo passati yaṁ passati yena passati, so passati taṁ passati tena passatīti?
analyzed: nanu yaḥ passati yam passati yena passati so passati tam passati tena passati iti
translated: “When someone sees, what they see, and the way they see, is that seeing, that what is seen, and that the way it is seen?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci yo passati yaṁ passati yena passati, so passati taṁ passati tena passati;
analyzed: āmantā  hañci yaḥ passati yam passati yena passati saḥ passati tam passati tena passati
translated: “Yes.”
“Well then, it must be said that
‘a person is found in a real and ultimate way.’”
“It shouldn’t be said that

original: “passāmahaṁ, bhikkhave, dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāmī”ti.
analyzed: passāmaha bhikkhave dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathā kamma upage satte pajānāmi iti

analyzed: passāmaha bhikkhave dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte cavamāne

original: upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāmī”ti

original: katvā teneva kāraṇena puggalo upalabbhati saccikaṭṭhaparamatthenāti?

original: Bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena rūpaṁ passati puggalaṁ passatīti?
analyzed: bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena rūpam passati puggalam passati iti
translated: “Does the Blessed One, with his divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, see form and see a person?”
“He sees form.”

original: Rūpaṁ puggalo, rūpaṁ cavati, rūpaṁ upapajjati, rūpaṁ yathākammūpaganti?
analyzed: rūpam puggalaḥ rūpam cavati rūpam upapajjati rūpam yathākammūpaganti

original: Bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena rūpaṁ passati puggalaṁ passatīti?
analyzed: bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena rūpam passati puggalam passati iti

original: Puggalo rūpaṁ rūpāyatanaṁ rūpadhātu nīlaṁ pītakaṁ lohitakaṁ odātaṁ cakkhuviññeyyaṁ cakkhusmiṁ paṭihaññati, cakkhussa āpāthaṁ āgacchatīti?

original: Bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena rūpaṁ passati puggalaṁ passatīti?

original: Khandhā saṅkhatā, nibbānaṁ asaṅkhataṁ, puggalo neva saṅkhato nāsaṅkhatoti?
analyzed: khandhāḥ saṅkhatāḥ nibbānam asaṅkhata puggalaḥ na iva saṅkhataḥ na asaṅkhataḥ ti
translated: Are the aggregates conditioned, Nibbāna unconditioned, and the person neither conditioned nor unconditioned?
You say ‘Yes.’ …

original: Aññe khandhā, aññaṁ nibbānaṁ, añño puggaloti?
analyzed: aññe khandhāḥ aññam nibbāna aññaḥ puggalo ti
translated: Are the aggregates one thing, Nibbāna another, and the person yet another?
You say ‘No.’ …

original: Rūpaṁ saṅkhataṁ, nibbānaṁ asaṅkhataṁ, puggalo neva saṅkhato nāsaṅkhatoti?
analyzed: rūpam saṅkhata nibbānam asaṅkhata puggalaḥ na iva saṅkhataḥ na asaṅkhataḥ ti
translated: “Material form is conditioned, Nibbāna is unconditioned, but a person is neither conditioned nor unconditioned”?
“Yes.”

original: Aññaṁ rūpaṁ, aññaṁ nibbānaṁ, añño puggaloti?
analyzed: aññam aññam nibbāna añño puggalo ti
translated: “Material form is one thing, Nibbāna is another, but a person is neither material form nor Nibbāna”?

analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe  vedanā  saññā
translated: “No.”🔽“Feeling is conditioned …
Perception is conditioned …

original: viññāṇaṁ saṅkhataṁ, nibbānaṁ asaṅkhataṁ, puggalo neva saṅkhato nāsaṅkhatoti?
analyzed: viññāṇam saṅkhata nibbānam asaṅkhata puggalaḥ na iva saṅkhataḥ na asaṅkhataḥ ti
translated: “ volitional formations are conditioned, Nibbāna is unconditioned, but a person is neither conditioned nor unconditioned”?
“Yes.”

original: Aññaṁ viññāṇaṁ, aññaṁ nibbānaṁ, añño puggaloti?
analyzed: aññam viññāṇa aññam nibbāna añño puggalo ti
translated: “Consciousness is one thing, Nibbāna is another, but a person is neither consciousness nor Nibbāna”?
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye faculty and the eye consciousness?” …

original: Puggalassa uppādo paññāyati, vayo paññāyati, ṭhitassa aññathattaṁ paññāyatīti?
analyzed: puggalassa uppādo paññāyati vayaḥ paññāyati ṭhitassa aññathattam paññāyati iti
translated: “The arising of a person is evident, the passing away of a person is evident, and the change of a person in the present is evident”?
“Yes.”
“Is a person conditioned”?
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …
The Blessed One has said:

analyzed: tīṇi imāni bhikkhave saṅkhatassa saṅkhata lakkhaṇāni
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these three characteristics of what is conditioned.

original: Saṅkhatānaṁ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṁ uppādo paññāyati, vayo paññāyati, ṭhitānaṁ aññathattaṁ paññāyatī”ti.
analyzed: saṅkhatāna bhikkhave dhammānam uppādaḥ paññāyati vayaḥ paññāyati ṭhitānam aññathattam paññāyati iti
translated: The arising of what is conditioned is evident, the passing away of what is conditioned is evident, and the change in what is conditioned from one state to another is evident.”

original: Puggalassa uppādo paññāyati, vayo paññāyati, ṭhitassa aññathattaṁ paññāyati;
analyzed: puggalassa uppādo paññāyati vayaḥ paññāyati ṭhitassa aññathattam paññāyati
translated: “The arising of a person is evident, the passing away of a person is evident, and the change in the person while standing is evident.
“Then the person is fabricated.”

original: Puggalassa na uppādo paññāyati, na vayo paññāyati, na ṭhitassa aññathattaṁ paññāyatīti?
analyzed: puggalassa na uppādo paññāyati na vayaḥ paññāyati na ṭhitassa aññathattam paññāyati iti
translated: “The arising of a person is not evident, the passing away of a person is not evident, and the change in the person while standing is not evident.”
“Yes.”🔽“The person is unfabricated.”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …
It has been said by the Blessed One:

analyzed: tīṇi imāni bhikkhave asaṅkhatassa asaṅkhata lakkhaṇāni
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these three characteristics of the unfabricated.

original: Asaṅkhatānaṁ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṁ na uppādo paññāyati, na vayo paññāyati, na ṭhitānaṁ aññathattaṁ paññāyatī”ti.
analyzed: asaṅkhatāna bhikkhave dhammānam na uppādaḥ paññāyati na vayaḥ paññāyati na ṭhitānam aññathattam paññāyati iti
translated: The arising of unfabricated dhammas is not evident; their passing away is not evident; and while they stand, change is not evident in them.”

original: Puggalassa na uppādo paññāyati, na vayo paññāyati, na ṭhitassa aññathattaṁ paññāyati;
analyzed: puggalassa na uppādo paññāyati na vayaḥ paññāyati na ṭhitassa aññathattam paññāyati
translated: “The arising of a person is not evident, the passing away of a person is not evident, and the change in the person while standing is not evident.
“Then the person is unfabricated.”

analyzed: parinibbutaḥ puggalaḥ attha atthamhi na ttha atthamhi iti
translated: “Is a person who has attained Nibbana both existent and non-existent?”
“He is existent.”

analyzed: parinibbutaḥ puggalaḥ sassatoti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: “Is a person who has attained Nibbana permanent?”🔽“No.” …
“He is non-existent.”
Is a person who has attained final Nibbāna cut off?
You say: “That is not so.” …
“On what is a person established?”
“On existence.”

original: Bhavo anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno khayadhammo vayadhammo virāgadhammo nirodhadhammo vipariṇāmadhammoti?
analyzed: bhavaḥ aniccaḥ saṅkhataḥ paṭicca samuppanno khaya dhammo vaya dhammo virāga dhammo nirodha dhammo vipariṇāma dhammo ti
translated: “Is existence impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation?”
“Yes.”

original: Puggalopi anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno khayadhammo vayadhammo virāgadhammo nirodhadhammo vipariṇāmadhammoti?
analyzed: puggalaḥ api aniccaḥ saṅkhataḥ paṭicca samuppanno khaya dhammo vaya dhammo virāga dhammo nirodha dhammo vipariṇāma dhammo ti
translated: “Is a person impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation?”
You say: “That is not so.” …
You should not say:
“A person is found as a real, ultimate fact.”
“Yes.”

original: Nanu atthi koci sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamāno “sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyāmī”ti pajānātīti?
analyzed: nanu atthi koci sukham vedanam vediyamānaḥ sukham vedanam vediyāmi iti pajānāti iti
translated: “Is there anyone who, when he feels a pleasant feeling, understands: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling’?”
“Yes.”

original: Hañci atthi koci sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamāno “sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyāmī”ti pajānāti, tena vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: hañci atthi koci sukham vedanam vediyamānaḥ sukham vedanam vediyāmi iti pajānāti tena vata re vattabbe
translated: “Then you should say:
‘A person is found as a real, ultimate fact.’
You should not say:
“Is a person found in a real and ultimate way?”
“Yes.”

original: Nanu atthi koci dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamāno …pe…
analyzed: nanu atthi koci dukkham vedanam vediyamāno pe
translated: “Isn’t there someone who, when feeling a painful feeling, knows ‘I am feeling a painful feeling’?

original: adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamāno “adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyāmī”ti pajānātīti?
analyzed: adukkham asukham vedanam vediyamānaḥ adukkham asukham vedanam vediyāmi iti pajānāti iti
translated: When feeling a neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling, does he know ‘I am feeling a neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling’?”
“Yes.”

original: Hañci atthi koci adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamāno “adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyāmī”ti pajānāti, tena vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: hañci atthi koci adukkham asukham vedanam vediyamānaḥ adukkham asukham vedanam vediyāmi iti pajānāti tena vata re vattabbe
translated: “Well then, it must be said that
a person is found in a real and ultimate way.”

original: Atthi koci sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamāno “sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyāmī”ti pajānātīti katvā tena ca kāraṇena puggalo upalabbhati saccikaṭṭhaparamatthenāti?
analyzed: atthi koci sukham vedanam vediyamānaḥ sukham vedanam vediyāmi iti pajānāti iti katvā tena ca kāraṇena puggalaḥ upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena ati
translated: “Is it because there is someone who, when feeling a pleasant feeling, knows ‘I am feeling a pleasant feeling’, and because of that reason, that a person is found in a real and ultimate way?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Yo sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamāno “sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyāmī”ti pajānāti, sveva puggalo;
analyzed: āmantā  yaḥ sukham vedanam vediyamānaḥ sukham vedanam vediyāmi iti pajānāti su eva puggalaḥ

original: yo sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamāno “sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyāmī”ti na pajānāti, na so puggaloti?
analyzed: yaḥ sukham vedanam vediyamānaḥ sukham vedanam vediyāmi iti na pajānāti na saḥ puggalaḥ ti

original: Yo dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamāno …pe…🔽yo adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamāno “adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyāmī”ti pajānāti, sveva puggalo;

analyzed: yaḥ adukkham asukham vedanam vediyamānaḥ adukkham asukham vedanam vediyāmi iti na pajānāti na saḥ puggalaḥ ti
translated: the person who feels a neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling the same as, or different from, the person who understands thus: ‘I am experiencing a neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling’?
“Then is it neither the same nor not the same?”

original: Atthi koci sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamāno “sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyāmī”ti pajānātīti katvā tena ca kāraṇena puggalo upalabbhati saccikaṭṭhaparamatthenāti?
analyzed: atthi koci sukham vedanam vediyamānaḥ sukham vedanam vediyāmi iti pajānāti iti katvā tena ca kāraṇena puggalaḥ upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena ati
translated: “Is it because one who feels a pleasant feeling understands thus: ‘I am experiencing a pleasant feeling’ that the person exists in an ultimate sense?”

You say: “You should not say: ‘The person who does not abide contemplating the body as a body is not a person.’“
Is the person who does not abide contemplating feelings as feelings…

analyzed: citte  dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati su eva puggalaḥ  yaḥ na dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati na so puggalaḥ ti
translated: contemplating mind as mind…🔽contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects a person?
You say: “You should not say: ‘The person who does not abide contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects is not a person.’“

original: Atthi koci kāye kāyānupassī viharatīti katvā tena ca kāraṇena puggalo upalabbhati saccikaṭṭhaparamatthenāti?
analyzed: atthi koci kāye kāya anupassī viharati iti katvā tena ca kāraṇena puggalaḥ upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena ati
translated: Is it because there is someone who abides contemplating the body as a body that a person is known as a real, ultimate fact?
You say: “Yes.”

original: Añño kāyo, añño kāye kāyānupassī viharatīti?
analyzed: añño kāyaḥ añño kāye kāya anupassī viharati iti
translated: Is it because there is a body and someone who abides contemplating the body as a body that a person is known as a real, ultimate fact?

analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe pe  aññā vedanā
translated: You say: “You should not say: ‘There is a body and someone who abides contemplating the body as a body.’“
Is it because there are feelings and someone who abides contemplating feelings as feelings…🔽is there a mind and someone who abides contemplating the mind as mind…

original: aññe dhammā, añño dhammesu dhammānupassī viharatīti?
analyzed: aññe dhammāḥ aññaḥ dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati iti
translated: are there mind-objects and someone who abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects that a person is known as a real, ultimate fact?
You say: “You should not say: ‘There are mind-objects and someone who abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects.’“
Is it because there is a person that a person is known as a real, ultimate fact?
You say: “Yes.”
Has it not been said by the Blessed One:
“Look upon the world as empty,
Mogharāja, always mindful;
Having shaken off the view of self,
thus one will cross over the bondage of death.
When he contemplates the world in this way,
the King of Death does not see him.”
Is there such a suttas?
“Yes.”
“Then you should not say that an individual can be discerned that is truly existent in the ultimate sense.”
“Does an individual contemplate?”
“Yes.”

original: Saha rūpena avekkhati, vinā rūpena avekkhatīti?
analyzed: saha rūpena avekkhati vinā rūpena avekkhati iti
translated: “Does he contemplate together with form, or does he contemplate without form?”
“He contemplates together with form.”
“Is that living being that body?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: vinā rūpena avekkhatīti, aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīranti?
analyzed: vinā rūpena avekkhati iti aññam jīvam aññam sarīran ti
translated: “Does he contemplate without form, so that the living being is one thing and the body another?”
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye faculty and the eye consciousness?” …

“Yes.”

“He contemplates internally.”
“Is that living being that body?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

“You should not say that
an individual can be discerned that is truly existent in the ultimate sense.”
“Yes.”

“Yes.”

“Yes.”

“Yes.”
